name: Tomato Egg Drop Soup
description: Classic soup that reminds me of my childhood. I'm not the biggest fan of tomatoes and eggs, a classic Chinese combination, but this was an excellent soup.

recipe.0: Heat the oil in a soup pot or wok over medium low heat. Add the tomato chunks and stir-fry for 5 minutes until the tomatoes are softened and start to fall apart.
recipe.1: Add in 1 cup chicken stock, 2 cups water, 2 teaspoons light soy sauce, 1/2 teaspoon sesame oil, 1/4 teaspoon ground white pepper and salt to taste. Bring to a boil, and then lower the heat so that the soup is simmering with the lid on.
recipe.2: Now quickly beat the egg in a small bowl and prepare the cornstarch slurry in a separate bowl.
recipe.3: Use a ladle to slowly swirl the soup in a whirlpool motion. Keep swirling as you pour in the cornstarch slurry until well incorporated. Now pour a thin stream of egg into the middle of the whirlpool as you slowly swirl the soup. This is how you get that pretty egg drop effect.
recipe.4: Serve hot or at room temperature. Ladle the soup into bowls and garnish with chopped scallions and cilantro, if using.

name: Chinese pork bone soup recipe with tomatoes, potatoes, and corn
description: The flavor combination of sweet corn, tomatoes, and hearty potatoes comes together in a red-hued soup that tastes amazing all year-round. Salt—the only seasoning in this recipe—makes the whole thing come alive.

recipe.0: Soak the pork bones for 1 hour with enough cold water to cover them completely. Rinse 2-3 times until the water runs clear. (If substituting chicken, you can skip this step.)
recipe.1: Add the bones to a large, thick-bottomed soup pot, cover with fresh water, cover, and bring to a boil. Once boiling, let it boil for 1 minute, then drain through a colander. Rinse the pork bones clean, drain, and set aside.
recipe.2: Wash the pot and dry it thoroughly. Heat it over medium heat, and add the oil, tomato paste (if using), and the tomatoes. Cook for 5 minutes, or until the tomatoes are softened. Add the 9 cups of water, along with the pork bones and corn. Cover, increase the heat to high, and bring the soup to a boil.
recipe.3: Once boiling, reduce the heat to medium-low. Cover and simmer for 1 hour (for ribs or chicken) or 90 minutes (for neck bones).
recipe.4: Next, add the potato chunks, cover, and bring the soup to a boil once again. Reduce the heat to medium low and simmer for another 30 minutes, until potatoes are tender. Skim off the grease floating on the surface of the soup (optional), and stir in the salt. Serve the soup with salt, so that each person can add more to taste before enjoying. Serve the pork or chicken from the soup with light soy sauce for dipping.

name: Salted Pork Bone Soup
description: Homestyle comfort food recipe. The addition of glass noodles makes this an extra satisfying meal. Great for the family.

recipe.0: Heat your soup pot over high heat until it just starts to smoke. Reduce the heat to medium-high. Add 2 tablespoons of oil to evenly coat the bottom, then add the salted pork bones in a single layer. Brown the bones on all sides until light golden brown, taking care not to burn them, which will cause your soup to taste bitter.
recipe.1: While the meat is browning, boil the water in a separate pot. Once the meat is done, carefully pour the boiling water into the soup pot.
recipe.2: Increase the heat to high to quickly bring the soup to a boil. Add the ginger slices, cover, reduce the heat to medium low, and simmer for 1 ½ to 2 hours. (If using, add the soaked dried squid, conch, or dried scallops plus the liquid it soaked in along with the ginger.)
recipe.3: Soak the mung bean vermicelli or sweet potato glass noodles, submerging them in cool water so they soften as the soup cooks. They won’t need to cook for very long.
recipe.4: Wash the napa cabbage (or your leafy green of your choice). Shake off excess water, and cut the cabbage into bite-sized pieces.
recipe.5: After 1 ½ to 2 hours of cooking, add the napa cabbage. Increase the heat to high to bring the soup to a boil. Cover, reduce the heat to medium, and cook for another 5 minutes until the cabbage is tender (or if using a more tender leafy green like bok choy, cook for 1 to 2 minutes).
recipe.6: If you are using cooked rice or potato starch noodles instead of glass noodles, this is the time to add them.
recipe.7: Season with salt and white pepper to taste. Before serving, add the mung bean vermicelli, scallions, and cilantro. Bring the soup to a boil and serve.

name: Tomato Hot Pot with Beef
description: The tart and sweet tomatoes provide the perfect contrast to the marbled, thinly sliced beef. Enoki mushrooms and mung bean vermicelli both add additional textural contrast for a warming, satisfying meal.

recipe.0: Place the bundle of mung bean vermicelli in a bowl of warm water to soak until softened, about 15 minutes. Trim the ends off the enoki mushrooms, and lightly rinse them of any dirt, separating them into smaller sections as you go (each bundle of mushrooms should be about 1/2 inch thick). Set the noodles and mushrooms aside.
recipe.1: Bring a medium pot of water to a boil. Use a sharp paring knife to cut an X into the bottom of each tomato, which will make it easier to peel after blanching. Carefully lower the tomatoes into the boiling water, and blanch for 30 seconds. Use a slotted spoon to remove the tomatoes from the water, and set aside to cool.
recipe.2: Bring the water back up to a boil, and add the beef. Cook for 15 seconds, or until the beef just turns opaque, and any foam rises to the surface. Remove the beef from the pot, and set aside.
recipe.3: Separate the green and white parts of the scallions. Cut the white parts on a diagonal into 1 to 2 inch pieces. Finely chop the green parts. By now, your tomatoes should be cool enough to peel. Peel the skin off, and cut into 1-inch chunks.
recipe.4: In a soup pot (preferably a Chinese ceramic soup pot if you have it!) over medium heat, add the oil, along with the white parts of the scallions and the ginger slices. Cook for 1-2 minutes, until fragrant.
recipe.5: Add the garlic and tomato paste, and cook for 30 seconds, until the oil turns a reddish-orange color. Add the tomatoes, along with the light soy sauce, sugar, and sesame oil. Fry the tomatoes until they break down a bit, about 3 minutes.
recipe.6: Add the chicken stock and water, and bring to a boil. Cover, turn the heat down, and simmer for 5 to 10 minutes. Add the enoki mushrooms and vermicelli, cover, and simmer for another 3 to 5 minutes.
recipe.7: Stir in the beef, white pepper and salt to taste. Garnish with cilantro the chopped scallion greens. Serve with steamed rice!

name: Thanksgiving Turkey Congee
description: Interesting use of Thanksgiving leftovers. Nothing like a warm bowl of congee.

recipe.0: In a very large stock pot, add the turkey carcass and all the veggies. Pour in the water and the rice, and bring everything to a boil. Let it simmer for 90 minutes. Use tongs to remove any bones, etc. Season with salt, white pepper, and garnish with scallion and cilantro.
recipe.1: Now, that's the way we've always done it. But if you want a really smooth congee, you can do it a slightly different way. Rather than adding the rice to the pot at the beginning, simply add the carcass, vegetables, and water to the stock pot. Simmer for 2 hours until you have a rich stock.
recipe.2: Remove any large bones and then strain the stock into a clean pot. Add the rice, bring to a boil, and simmer for another 90 minutes. Stir in some leftover shredded turkey, season with salt and pepper, and garnish with scallions and cilantro.

name: Button Mushroom Soup
description: I love mushrooms and I love mushroom soups. This one is a hit.

recipe.0: Wash the mushrooms clean of any dirt, and dry them thoroughly with a clean kitchen towel. Detach the stems (you will add them to the soup also).
recipe.1: Place a medium soup pot over medium high heat. When the pan is very hot, add the oil and mushrooms cup-side up in a single layer. (Add the stems in too to avoid waste.)
recipe.2: Reduce the heat to medium, and cook until the mushroom caps are browned, and each cup fills with liquid (that’s the juices in the mushroom seeping out!). Also check the stems for browning. Avoid stirring during this pan-frying process as it’s the key step to developing flavor for this soup. (You also want to keep the mushroom juices in the caps.)
recipe.3: When the mushrooms are nicely browned, add the water and light soy sauce. Bring to a boil. Cover and simmer for 5 minutes over medium low heat.
recipe.4: Add salt to taste, and stir in the cornstarch slurry (if using). Simmer the soup for 30 seconds until thickened.
recipe.5: Just before serving, add the cilantro and scallions. If you like cilantro (like me) this soup can take a lot of cilantro!

name: Tom Yum Soup
description: Honestly, could have this soup any time of the year. I'm not a huge fan of acidic soups though.

recipe.0: Add 3 cups of water, and bring to a simmer. Cover, and simmer for 10 minutes. Add the vegetable stock.
recipe.1: Take the lemongrass, and trim away the dry reedy bit about halfway up the stalk, and then trim the base. Peel the tough outer layers away to reveal the more tender center. Smash the lemon grass using a mallet or heavy rolling pin (one without handles).
recipe.2: Cut the smashed lemongrass stalk into 2-inch (5 cm) lengths, and add it to the broth in the wok. Also add the shallots, cilantro stem, galangal, lime leaves, and thai chilies.
recipe.3: Bring to a simmer, cover, and simmer for 10 minutes. After 10 minutes, you can remove the inedible herbs and aromatics from the pot using a fine-meshed strainer, but we like to leave them in, as is traditional in Thailand.
recipe.4: Add the mushrooms, and simmer for another 5 minutes. Stir in the sugar, Thai chili paste and fish sauce. Stir until the chili paste has fully dissolved in the soup.
recipe.5: Add the lime juice to your serving bowl, and ladle the hot tom yum soup into the bowl. (You don’t want to cook the lime juice. You want to preserve its fresh flavor. You also want to avoid putting large amounts of acidic lime juice into your wok, which can wear away the patina).

name: Bitter Melon Soup with Pork Bones
description: Classic comfort food. My mom made this a lot and I find myself craving it during cold days.

recipe.0: Soak the pearl barley for at least 2 hours or overnight. Drain and set aside. Also soak the pork bones in cold water for 1-2 hours to purge them of impurities, changing the water once halfway through.
recipe.1: Rinse the pork bones clean, using your hands to scrub them of any impurities and bone spurs. Transfer to a deep stock pot with just enough water to submerge them. Bring to a boil, and boil for 1 minute. Remove from the heat, rinse the pork bones clean, discard the water, and rinse the soup pot clean.
recipe.2: Add the pork bones back to the stock pot, along with soaked barley, dates, 8 cups water and the ginger slices. Set over high heat, and bring to a boil. Once boiling, immediately turn the heat down to medium low, cover, and simmer for 2 hours.
recipe.3: While the soup is simmering, slice the bitter melon in half lengthwise. Use a spoon to scoop out the seeds and scrape away all of the white pith, which can be particularly bitter. Cut each half into large chunks. Set aside.
recipe.4: After 2 hours of simmering, skim the fat off the surface of the soup. Add the bitter melon, cover, and simmer for another 30 minutes. Add salt to taste before serving (you can also add MSG for extra oomph if desired—this is completely optional!). Serve with light soy sauce to dip the tender pork ribs into.

name: Chinese chicken broth
description: It’s the perfect canvas for all the recipes on the blog that call for chicken stock, from soups to wontons and noodles. It will also up your game for stir-fries and braises! Unlike Western chicken stocks and broths, which use a mix of vegetables and herbs, this is a clear, pure-tasting Chinese chicken broth, flavored just with ginger and scallions.

recipe.0: Add the raw chicken drumsticks and bones, ginger, and scallions to your Instant Pot. Add 12 cups of water. (We have an 8 qt. Instant Pot. If yours is smaller, scale down the recipe accordingly. Make sure your liquid levels do not exceed the max-fill line.)
recipe.1: Seal the lid of your Instant Pot. Set it to manual high pressure for 45 minutes. Once it beeps, it’s on, but it will take about 15-20 minutes to come up to high pressure, in addition to the 45 minutes of cooking time.
recipe.2: When it’s done, allow the Instant Pot to release pressure naturally for at least 30 minutes and carefully turn the venting knob to “venting” to finish releasing pressure. Alternatively, just let the pressure release gradually until the float valve/pressure indicator drops.
recipe.3: When it’s safe to do so, carefully remove the lid. If you’re using the stock right away, carefully ladle the broth out to ensure it’s clear. If you’re planning on storing it, remove the chicken, let the broth cool, and let the sediment settle. Then transfer it to reusable freezer containers for later use.
recipe.4: The broth will last in the refrigerator for 3-4 days. Freeze for up to 6 months, though it tastes best when used within 3 months.

name: Spiced Vegan Lentil Soup
description: Better than I thought a vegan lentil soup would be. Complex for a soup though

recipe.0: Warm the olive oil in a large Dutch oven or pot over medium heat. One-fourth cup olive oil may seem like a lot, but it adds a lovely richness and heartiness to this nutritious soup.
recipe.1: Once the oil is shimmering, add the chopped onion and carrot and cook, stirring often, until the onion has softened and is turning translucent, about 5 minutes.
recipe.2: Add the garlic, cumin, curry powder and thyme. Cook until fragrant while stirring constantly, about 30 seconds. Pour in the drained diced tomatoes and cook for a few more minutes, stirring often, in order to enhance their flavor.
recipe.3: Pour in the lentils, broth and the water. Add 1 teaspoon salt and a pinch of red pepper flakes. Season generously with freshly ground black pepper. Raise heat and bring the mixture to a boil, then partially cover the pot and reduce the heat to maintain a gentle simmer. Cook for 25 to 30 minutes, or until the lentils are tender but still hold their shape.
recipe.4: Transfer 2 cups of the soup to a blender. Securely fasten the lid, protect your hand from steam with a tea towel placed over the lid, and purée the soup until smooth. Pour the puréed soup back into the pot. (Or, use an immersion blender to blend a portion of the soup.)
recipe.5: Add the chopped greens and cook for 5 more minutes, or until the greens have softened to your liking. Remove the pot from the heat and stir in 1 tablespoon of lemon juice. Taste and season with more salt, pepper and/or lemon juice until the flavors really sing. For spicier soup, add another pinch or two of red pepper flakes.
recipe.6: Serve while hot. Leftovers will keep well for about 4 days in the refrigerator, or can be frozen for several months (just defrost before serving).

name: 20-Minute Fish Congee
description: Congee is a great breakfast food in particular, as it’s popular at dim sum restaurants and Chinatown noodle soup spots. It’s warm, filling, and easy to digest. It’s also a great starter food for babies.

recipe.0: Wash the rice 1-2 times, mixing it in the water with your hands before discarding the starchy water. Submerge and soak the rice for 30 minutes.
recipe.1: Drain and transfer to a resealable bag or other freezer-safe container. Freeze for at least 8 hours.
recipe.2: In a medium bowl, marinate the fish with salt, white pepper, oyster sauce, Shaoxing wine, and ginger. Use your hands to toss the fish to coat. Add the egg white, and gently mix until the marinade feels slippery and each fish chunk is well-coated.
recipe.3: Cover the bowl with an overturned plate and transfer to the refrigerator for 15 minutes to marinate while you start the congee.
recipe.4: In a large pot, bring 8-9 cups of stock and the frozen rice to a boil (no need to defrost the rice). Cover, leaving the lid slightly ajar to avoid the congee boiling over, and reduce the heat to medium low. Simmer for 10 minutes. Do not stir.
recipe.5: While the congee cooks, wash and finely chop the romaine lettuce and very thinly julienne the ginger. Don’t prepare the ginger ahead of time, as you want the flavor of freshly cut ginger.
recipe.6: After 10 minutes, increase the heat to medium high, and stir the congee continuously for a couple of minutes to thicken. Stir in the lettuce, and bring to a boil to wilt the lettuce.
recipe.7: Finally, add the fish pieces, gently stirring to distribute them. (If you don’t like the taste of raw ginger in your congee, you can add the ginger at this point, along with the fish fillets.) Bring to a boil, and add additional salt and white pepper to taste. Serve topped with scallions, cilantro, and ginger if desired.

name: Seaweed egg drop soup
description: Common soup served with any meal, very versatile. Can be made with chicken stock, veggie stock, or water.

recipe.0: Toast the dried seaweed in a clean, dry wok over medium heat for 1-2 minutes on each side. Remove from the wok and set aside.
recipe.1: Add the stock and water to a wok or pot, and bring it to a boil. Add the dried shrimp flakes (if using), sesame oil, white pepper, and toasted seaweed. Stir and bring to a boil again.
recipe.2: With the stock boiling, stir in the beaten eggs, and then the chopped scallions. Bring to a boil once again, and serve immediately.

recipe.0: Make wontons or boil store-bought wontons.
recipe.1: With the wontons made, assemble the soup. This recipe uses just 5 cups of chicken broth with the expectation that you’ll freeze half of the wontons for another day. 5 cups of broth is enough for 4 servings.
recipe.2: Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a soup pot. Sweat the onions until they’re translucent. Add the carrots and celery, and cook for about 2 minutes. Add the broth, and simmer, covered for about 20 minutes, until the vegetables are tender. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
recipe.3: Bring a separate pot of water to a boil for your wontons. Boil them for 5-6 minutes (for fresh wontons) or 7-8 minutes (for frozen wontons). Divide into bowls and top with the hot soup.

name: Asian Vegetable Stock
description: Great, versatile. A lot of work.

recipe.0: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Take your napa cabbage half, and cut it in half again lengthwise. Place the cabbage on a sheet pan and drizzle lightly with oil. Roast for 25 minutes.
recipe.1: Meanwhile, in a large stockpot, heat 1 tablespoon oil over medium heat. Add the ginger and garlic and cook for 2 minutes, until fragrant but not browned. Add the fermented bean curd and cook for another minute. Then add the onion, carrots, scallions, daikon, kelp, dried shiitake mushrooms, and water. When the napa cabbage is done roasting, add it to the pot as well.
recipe.2: Bring to a boil, turn the heat down to low, and simmer with the lid on for 4 hours. Strain the stock, and season with salt to taste.

name: Laksa Noodle Soup
description: Laksa is spicy, fragrant noodle soup found across Southeast Asia, particularly Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. It consists of noodles (either wheat noodles, rice vermicelli, or egg noodles/hokkien noodles) in a thick broth made with spices, fresh aromatics, shrimp paste, and coconut milk. Common toppings include fried tofu puffs, fish cakes, blanched cockles, chicken, shrimp, minced laksa leaves, bean sprouts and other vegetables. This is delicious.

recipe.0: Preheat your oven to 400 degrees F. Season the chicken thighs with salt and pepper (we used white pepper, but you can also use black pepper), and place on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Bake in the oven for 40 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside.
recipe.1: While the chicken is cooking, heat 2 tablespoons vegetable oil in a large saucepan or medium pot over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and ginger and cook for 1 minute. Add the minced lemongrass and chilies, and cook for 3 minutes.
recipe.2: Add the laksa paste and brown sugar. Fry for another 3 minutes, letting all the flavors meld together. Add the chicken stock, coconut milk, and fish sauce. Bring to a boil. Add the soy puffs, cover, and allow to simmer for 10 minutes.
recipe.3: Meanwhile, rinse the noodles in warm water (for cooked hokkien noodles or rice vermicelli) or prepare according to package instructions (for fresh or dried wheat noodles). Distribute among four large noodle soup bowls.
recipe.4: Shred the cooked chicken and skin and distribute among the bowls. Pour any juices from the roasting pan into the broth. (You can even use a little bit of warm water to scrape any lingering tasty bits off the parchment paper).
recipe.5: Season the broth with lime juice and more fish sauce to taste, until your broth has reached your desired levels of saltiness/sourness. If you would rather not use fish sauce as your salting agent (it can be quite pungent to some palates), season with salt instead.
recipe.6: Meanwhile, toss the thinly sliced shallots in flour until they’re lightly coated. In a cast iron pan, heat an additional 2 tablespoons oil. Fry the shallots until crispy and set aside.
recipe.7: Season the shrimp with salt and pepper and sear them in the same oil you used to cook the shallots, just until they’re cooked through.
recipe.8: To assemble the laksa, pour the broth over the noodles and chicken, and add a couple pieces of soy puff to each. Top with the cooked shrimp, bean sprouts, cilantro, and fried shallots. Serve with extra lime wedges, and enjoy!

recipe.0: Layer all ingredients in a serving dish.
